Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Is Imprecise Supervision Useful? Leveraging Ambiguous, Incomplete or Conflicting Data Annotations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Supervised machine learning approaches to building predictive models from data traditionally rely on labeled samples. However, in many real-world applications, samples are either unlabeled or labeled imprecisely labeled, i.e., labels are often ambiguous, conflicting, or incomplete. This presents the problem of learning predictive models under imprecise supervision.

This project aims to develop effective algorithms to address three different scenarios that lead to imprecise supervision (1) multiple labelers with varying expertise are employed to annotate samples; (2) annotated labels are associated with a set of samples instead of an individual sample; (3) annotations are derived by modeling multiple expert assessments. The project introduces a general bi-convex programming, minimax optimization, and multi-objective optimization based framework for learning predictive models from imprecisely labeled data. The resulting algorithms will be evaluated on a number of real-world applications.

Broader Impacts: The results of this research are likely to impact a range of biomedical applications, including medical image labeling, longitudinal behavioral studies, genomics, and drug safety. The project offers enhanced opportunities for curriculum development and research-based advanced training of grauduate amd undergraduate students in machine learning and its applications. Dissemination of open source software implementation of algorithms resulting from the project also contribute to the project's broader impact. Additional information about the project can be found at: http://www.labhealthinfo.uconn.edu/home/MachineLearning.jsp

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examined the imprecisely-supervised learning problems. Unlike traditional supervised learning with precisely known labels or unsupervised learning with completely unknown labels, the imprecisely-supervised learning employs supervision labels that are limited, ambiguous, or conflicting. This project improved upon existing techniques and developed a set of algorithms to address (1) co-modeling of multi-view data, (2) multi-task learning, (3) learning from multiple annotations, and (4) longitudinal data analytics. We also explored data imputation or generation to deal with the data incompleteness problem. These techniques were employed to address real-world challenges to benefit public health and genetic studies of complex disease. The supported research has led to peer-reviewed articles including eight journal and ten conference publications with one best paper award.

For co-modeling of multi-view data, we developed four algorithms based on respectively singular value decomposition, matrix approximation, and multi-objective optimization, and assessed a variety of properties of these methods. For instance, a singular value decomposition based algorithm could run faster empirically than an algorithm based on matrix approximation for which however we obtained a global convergence proof. These algorithms were used to refine diagnostic classification of complex diseases. In four of the works, we used the methods to identify genetically important subtypes of substance use disorders. In another work, we used them to analyze smartphone data to detect depression subtypes.

For multi-task learning, we developed a feature learning method that can select the most important features for each learning task and simultaneously identify the features important across all tasks. This method was used to analyze smartphone data, and helped understand different depression patterns and identify the smartphone mobile features most indicative of depressive episodes.

For learning from multiple annotations where data were annotated by multiple labelers with inconsistent labels, we developed a min-max optimization framework to construct classifiers from the inconsistent labels. This method achieved better classification performance than the state of the art because it handled simultaneously two sources of label ambiguity: one from multiple annotators and the other from different instances observed for each individual data example.

The longitudinal data analytics was motivated by a real-life modeling challenge that we encountered when analyzing repeated measurements of EEG or fMRI assessment.  In such data analysis, features were measured at different spatial locations and at different time points. We developed a least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO) method that could determine both the relevant features and the most influential time points that predict the current label of a data subject. This method helped to analyze EEG data to understand schizophrenia in two works and helped to detect ear tubes from otoscopic images.

Other methodological advances under this grant include two new methods that deal with the miss data problem. One method used auxiliary features to impute missing data entries based on observed partial data, and the other method expanded the generative model of generative adversarial networks by employing statistical hypothesis testing.

Through this project, we developed course materials for a new graduate-level course for Computational Biomedical Informatics at the University of Connecticut that facilitated the widespread use of machine learning methods for public health. This project supported the work of five Ph.D. students and helped graduate two of them. The work was widely disseminated by presentations at nine conferences to a variety of machine learning methodological audiences and bioinformatics practitioners, by four open-source software packages, and through invited talks, such as one at NIH. Papers and software are available at our laboratory website at https://healthinfo.lab.uconn.edu/.

 


Last Modified: 11/23/2018
Modified by: Jinbo Bi
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This research examined the imprecisely-supervised learning problems. Unlike traditional supervised learning with precisely known labels or unsupervised learning with completely unknown labels, the imprecisely-supervised learning employs supervision labels that are limited, ambiguous, or conflicting. This project improved upon existing techniques and developed a set of algorithms to address (1) co-modeling of multi-view data, (2) multi-task learning, (3) learning from multiple annotations, and (4) longitudinal data analytics. We also explored data imputation or generation to deal with the data incompleteness problem. These techniques were employed to address real-world challenges to benefit public health and genetic studies of complex disease. The supported research has led to peer-reviewed articles including eight journal and ten conference publications with one best paper award. For co-modeling of multi-view data, we developed four algorithms based on respectively singular value decomposition, matrix approximation, and multi-objective optimization, and assessed a variety of properties of these methods. For instance, a singular value decomposition based algorithm could run faster empirically than an algorithm based on matrix approximation for which however we obtained a global convergence proof. These algorithms were used to refine diagnostic classification of complex diseases. In four of the works, we used the methods to identify genetically important subtypes of substance use disorders. The longitudinal data analytics was motivated by a real-life modeling challenge that we encountered when analyzing repeated measurements of EEG or fMRI assessment. Through this project, we developed course materials for a new graduate-level course for Computational Biomedical Informatics at the University of Connecticut that facilitated the widespread use of machine learning methods for public health.
